name: National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics
theoryOfChange: By uniting, supporting, and training Muslim charitable clinics, the association enhances their capability to provide high-quality care and expand services to underserved populations.

judge_issues.message: The risk summary mentions 'Board too small: 2 members' as the key concern, but the BBB profile indicates that the Virginia Association of Free and Charitable Clinics meets the standard for board size. This discrepancy should be investigated, as the BBB profile may not be for the correct organization.
Religious organization (Form 990-exempt) - limited financial data available
Missing mission: Mission statement needed for donor understanding
BBB name 'Virginia Association of Free and Charitable Clinics' may not match 'National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics' (similarity: 60%)

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

score_details.score_summary: National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics earns 28/100 due to moderate alignment and limited impact (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: The provided search results for 'National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics' (NAOMCC) do not explicitly mention the acceptance of zakat donations on their website or in their organizational descriptions. While they aim to support Muslim charitable clinics and serve underserved communities, there is no direct statement or dedicated fund indicating zakat acceptance.

all_citations.claim: The organization focuses on uniting healthcare organizations and supporting member clinics.
The organization is registered as a non-profit with specific program activities related to healthcare support.
The organization accepts donations through its website for general charitable purposes.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization receives a lower score due to significant gaps in financial transparency and a lack of verifiable impact data. While it addresses the urgent cause of global health, the low data confidence reflects a need for more public reporting.
areas_for_improvement: Limited public disclosure regarding mission statements and specific program outcomes
Lack of transparent financial data and third-party performance evaluations

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is moderate as the charity addresses the urgent cause of global health, yet it currently shows a low fit for typical Muslim donor expectations due to the lack of detailed organizational data [1]. Donors can contribute through general charitable giving or sadaqah [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization's impact score is low because there is limited evidence of program effectiveness or cost-per-beneficiary data available in public filings [1][2]. Its primary function is capacity building, but the direct results of these efforts remain unverified by third-party sources.

baseline_narrative.headline: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics serves as a unifying body for healthcare organizations to enhance community-based medical services.
strengths: Focuses on capacity building by uniting various healthcare organizations
Provides specialized support programs for member clinics
baseline_narrative.summary: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics (NAOMCC) is a non-profit organization focused on uniting healthcare organizations to improve service delivery [1]. The association provides dedicated support for its member organizations to strengthen the network of charitable medical clinics [1][2].

This organization meets all 20 Standards for Charity Accountability

areas_for_improvement.context: There is <cite id="1">insufficient data for cost-per-beneficiary calculation</cite> and the <cite id="1">program expense ratio is currently unknown</cite>.
The organization currently has a <cite id="1">baseline board governance with only 2 members</cite>, which presents a risk for oversight.

bbb_assessment.summary: Meets all 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance Standards for Charity Accountability

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is an emerging entity (founded roughly 3 years ago) and has successfully passed a BBB accountability review.
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="1">limited financial transparency</cite> and a <cite id="1">very small board of directors</cite>.

confidence.notes: Data is limited due to the organization's emerging status and lack of full rating.

alignment.explanation: While the organization has an <cite id="1">Islamic identity</cite>, it is currently <cite id="1">Sadaqah-eligible only</cite> and does not facilitate zakat payments.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be improved by <cite id="1">documenting a clear theory of change</cite> that illustrates the specific causal pathway from clinic support to community health outcomes.

credibility.explanation: Donors should note <cite id="1">low data confidence</cite> due to the absence of a full Charity Navigator rating and limited public filings. However, credibility is supported by <cite id="4">audited financial statements</cite> and a <cite id="4">pass status from the BBB</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="1">expand its board beyond 2 members</cite> and publish detailed annual impact reports.

impact.explanation: The impact score is limited because <cite id="1">beneficiary counts are not reported</cite>, making cost-effectiveness difficult to measure. The model is <cite id="1">indirect (capacity building)</cite> rather than direct service.
impact.improvement: The organization could improve by <cite id="1">tracking and reporting beneficiary counts</cite> to enable a clear cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the institutional growth of Muslim-led healthcare infrastructure in the US through sadaqah.
donor_motivations: Value the creation of a unified network for Muslim clinics
Interested in domestic healthcare advocacy and training
Comfortable supporting an emerging organization with a high funding gap
giving_considerations: Financial efficiency data is currently limited
Impact is indirect through member clinics rather than direct patient care
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those requiring rigorous, multi-year impact data and high financial transparency.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects an <cite id="1">emerging organization baseline</cite> with unverified outcomes and no external evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: By providing <cite id="1">education, training, and resource pooling</cite>, the organization strengthens member clinics, which in turn provide better care to the public.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that capacity-building efforts actually result in improved patient health outcomes at the clinic level.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As an emerging organization with an <cite id="1">unknown revenue base</cite>, there is significant capacity to absorb new funding for program expansion.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Unlike larger peers, NAOMCC focuses specifically on the <cite id="1">network of Muslim charitable clinics</cite> in the US.

strengths.detail: The organization excels at <cite id="1">uniting various healthcare organizations</cite> to share resources and improve service delivery efficiency.
NAOMCC provides <cite id="1">specialized support programs</cite> and <cite id="1">education and training</cite> to help member clinics maintain high standards of care.
The organization <cite id="4">meets all 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance Standards</cite> for Charity Accountability, indicating a commitment to basic governance.

strengths_deep_dive: The NAOMCC's primary strength lies in its role as a network hub. By focusing on <cite id="1">collaboration and resource pooling</cite>, it allows smaller clinics to benefit from a larger collective voice and shared expertise. This is evidenced by their <cite id="1">advocacy efforts</cite> which aim to bring attention to the needs of charitable medical providers. Furthermore, the organization maintains a <cite id="4">conflict of interest policy</cite> and undergoes <cite id="4">independent audits</cite>, which are critical trust signals for an emerging organization in the healthcare space.
rich_narrative.summary: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics (NAOMCC) functions as a <cite id="1">unifying body for healthcare organizations</cite> dedicated to enhancing community-based medical services across the United States. Operating primarily through a <cite id="1">capacity-building model</cite>, the organization focuses on <cite id="1">uniting healthcare organizations</cite> to strengthen the collective impact of charitable clinics serving vulnerable populations. Its core activities include <cite id="1">providing specialized support programs</cite> for member clinics, facilitating <cite id="1">collaboration and resource pooling</cite>, and conducting <cite id="1">education and training</cite> initiatives. While the organization plays a vital role in the <cite id="1">global health cause area</cite> by supporting domestic clinics, it currently operates with limited public financial disclosure. The organization is <cite id="3">registered as a 501(c)(3) non-profit</cite>, allowing for tax-deductible sadaqah contributions, but it lacks the extensive historical data or third-party impact evaluations typical of larger institutional charities. Its strategic focus remains on <cite id="1">advocacy efforts</cite> and building a robust network of clinics that can provide direct medical care to underserved communities.
